I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
loan to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam, (ii) a proposed grant to the Kingdom of Cambodia, 
and (iii) a proposed grant to the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) for the Greater 
Mekong Subregion (GMS) Biodiversity Conservation Corridors Project.1 
PF FP
 
2.  The  project2  will  enhance  transboundary  cooperation  for  preventing  and  mitigating 
PF FP
fragmentation of biodiversity rich forest landscapes of the Cardamom Mountains and Eastern 
Plains Dry Forest in Cambodia, Triborder Forest areas located in southern Lao PDR, and the 
Central Annamites in Viet Nam.3 The design of the biodiversity corridors4 is embedded within a 
PF FP PF FP
multiple  use  and  multilayered  landscape  approach.  Project  interventions  will  promote 
sustainable resource use, restore and improve vegetative cover in marginal lands, and address 
constraints  to  land  tenure  and  rural  household  access  to  socioeconomic  assets,  thereby 
enhancing the productivity of these landscapes. The project will (i) provide tenurial security to 
poor households and ethnic minority groups for collaborative management of forest resources; 
(ii) restore habitat on degraded forestlands with tree planting of native species, and agroforestry 
models with improved sources of nontimber forest products (NTFPs); (iii) improve livelihoods 
and income-enhancing small-scale infrastructure; (iv) generate over 5 million cash-based labor 
days through project activities; and (v) augment ecosystem service flows and benefits through 
carbon  sequestration  and  improved  watershed  management.  The  project  is  positioned  for 
multiple types of long-term financial support for expanded and sustained local and civil society 
engagement in natural resource management.5 The project will cover an area of more than 1.93 
PF FP
million hectares (ha) involving 22 communes in Cambodia, 69 villages in the Lao PDR, and 34 
communes in Viet Nam with a total population of 172,000 or 35,000 households, with 58% 
identified as ethnic minorities and more than 50% considered poor. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  The six GMS6 governments, with support from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and 
PF FP
nongovernment  organization  partners,  have  identified  the  most  important  biodiversity 
conservation landscapes in the GMS that are vulnerable to increased development pressures 
and  environmental  degradation  (attached  map).  These  regionally  and  globally  high-value 
biodiversity landscapes and watersheds need to be conserved to safeguard local livelihoods 
and investments in energy and hydropower, transport, water, and food security enhancing 
sectors. Recognizing this need, the GMS leaders endorsed the Core Environment Program and 
Biodiversity Conservation Corridors Initiative (CEP-BCI) at the Second GMS Summit in July

4  Biodiversity corridors are geographic areas within or cutting across GMS economic corridors that need to be placed 
P P

ecosystem services. They ensure the continuity of ecological processes between natural protected areas.

P P

Deforestation and Forest Degradation and Conservation and Enhancement of Carbon Stocks (REDD/REDD+) 
mechanisms and REDD carbon market opportunities.

2005, with the biodiversity corridors initiative (BCI) as the flagship component.7 The project

CEP-BCI.8 
PF FP
 
4.  The  development  of  GMS  transport  infrastructure  is  connecting  people,  natural 
resources,  and  markets;  and  acting  as  a  catalyst  for  broader  economic  development.    
Resource-rich,  relatively  remote  locations  such  as  Koh  Kong  and  Mondulkiri  provinces  in 
Cambodia, Attapeu and Sekong provinces in the Lao PDR, and Quang Nam and Quang Tri 
provinces in Viet Nam have recently been connected to markets through the development or 
upgrading  of  major  transboundary  roads  that  provide  the  backbone  of  the  North–South 
Economic  Corridor,  East–West  Economic  Corridor,  and  Southern  Economic  Corridor.  The 
investment  plans  to  convert  these  transport  corridors  into  economic  corridors  need  to  be 
embedded in an ecosystem management approach. Failure to do so risks jeopardizing the 
P P
nature  and  magnitude  of  ecosystem  service  flows,  including  biodiversity  conservation  and 
carbon sequestration benefits to local communities, and undermining the performance and 
sustainability of investments. 9 
PF FP
 
5.  Development  pressures. The development of regional hydropower systems, roads, 
large-scale tourism infrastructure, mining, and plantation agriculture ventures pose challenges 
to  these  biodiversity  conservation  landscapes.  Hydropower  development  of  more  than  
900 megawatts is envisaged in the project area.10 In the provinces of Attapeu, Champasak, and 
PF FP
Sekong, which are the focus of BCI landscapes connecting to the Lao PDR, nearly 97,000 ha 
are expected to be inundated from the planned hydropower investments.11 In addition, some 
PF FP
600,000  ha  are  under  various  mining  and  logging  concessions,  indicating  rapid  natural 
resources  sector-led  growth. 12  Similarly,  in  the  Cardamom  Mountains  in  Cambodia,  22 
PF FP
proposed hydropower stations will inundate large forest areas, while in Mondulkiri province in 
northeast Cambodia, 18 hydropower dams are proposed.13 In Viet Nam, the BCI sites spanning 
PF FP
1.7 million ha will come under increasing pressure with eight hydropower dams planned to meet 
the rapidly growing demand for electricity (15% per annum).14 In addition to the development of 
PF FP
productive sectors, climate change is likely to have an additional effect on ecosystem services. 
Increasing weather variability, and extreme weather events and shifts in agro-ecological zones 
are likely to increase vulnerability of ecosystem services and amplify impacts on dependent 
poor communities.15  
PF FP

6.  Policy and sectoral relevance. The project is in line with the GMS 10-year (2002–
2012) strategic framework thrust: protecting the environment and promoting sustainable use of 
shared natural resources. The project will contribute to pillar 4 of ADB's regional cooperation 
and integration strategy: cooperation in regional public goods. The project will also support the 
new  GMS  strategic  framework  (2012–2022),  currently  being  prepared,  and  the  process  of 
transitioning from GMS transport corridors into full-fledged economic corridors. Sustainable 
environmental management is a critical aspect of the poverty reduction strategies in Cambodia, 
the Lao PDR, and Viet Nam, with more than two-thirds of the population directly deriving their 
sustenance from natural resources and agricultural sectors. The project is aligned with the 
targets of the National Strategic Development Plan Update 2009–2013 of Cambodia; the draft 
VII National Socio Economic Development Plan 2011–2015 of the Lao PDR; and Article 9 of the 
recently  approved  Biodiversity  Law  (Law  No.  20/2008/QH12),  the  Forestry  Development 
Strategy to 2020 (Prime Minister Decision No. 18/2007/QD-TTg, 5 February 2007), and the 
overall socioeconomic development objectives of Viet Nam for 2011–2015. 
 
7.  Lessons from sector interventions and the CEP-BCI pilot phase. The project design 
is informed by lessons from ADB support to the Tonle Sap Initiative in Cambodia,16 and ongoing 
PF FP
sector interventions in the Lao PDR17 and Viet Nam.18 These overwhelmingly suggest that        
PF FP PF FP
(i) decentralized community-oriented management approaches offer the best chance of success 
in  addressing  environment  and  natural  resource  issues,  and  (ii)  provincial  coordination  of 
multisector interventions needs to go hand-in-hand with developing the implementation capacity 
of line agencies.19 The BCI pilot phase demonstrates that coupling conservation with direct 
PF FP
livelihood  improvement  is  feasible  as  demonstrated  by  piloting  conservation  stewardship 
programs delivering direct cash income of about $800,000 to more than 28,000 beneficiaries, 
and avoiding deforestation and forest degradation of more than 2 million ha.20 It also confirmed 
PF FP
that viable alternatives can be designed and deployed for (i) using local communities as willing 
and able service providers to undertake biodiversity restoration and conservation investments; 
(ii)  integrating  conservation  priorities  in  investment  decision-making  processes;  and                 
(iii) increasing the economic returns to hydropower and tourism investments through payment 
for ecosystem service policy and financial regimes. 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The  impact  of  the  project  will  be  climate-resilient  sustainable  forest  ecosystems 
benefiting local livelihoods. The project’s outcome will be sustainably managed biodiversity 
corridors in Cambodia, the Lao PDR, and Viet Nam.   
 
C.  Outputs 
 
9.  The outputs are (i) institutions and communities strengthened for biodiversity corridor 
management;  (ii)  biodiversity  corridors  restored,  protected,  and  maintained;  (iii)  livelihoods 
improved and small-scale infrastructure support provided in target villages and communes; and 
(iv) project management and support services operationalized.

10.  Output  1:  Institutions  and  communities  strengthened  for  biodiversity  corridor 
management. Investments under this output will focus on (i) strengthening the capacity of the 
national, provincial, district, and commune bodies for corridor planning and management; and 
(ii) providing protection and sustainable use policies, guidelines, and/or local regulations for 
enforcing  biodiversity  corridor  management  plans.  In  particular,  activities  will  contribute  to  
(i) management plans and corridor policy and legal framework covering around 1.93 million ha 
of forest and nonforest land in 56 communes and 69 villages spread across Cambodia, the Lao 
PDR, and Viet Nam; and (ii) participatory land use maps and commune and village investment 
plans with delineation and demarcation of permanent forest boundaries and provision of new 
land use certificates.  
 
11.  Output 2: Biodiversity corridors restored, protected, and maintained. The focus is 
on commune and village-based forest protection and restoration. The bulk of the investments 
under output 2 will target forest restoration, covering 19,200 ha in the form of natural forest 
replanting, enrichment planting, NTFP planting, and agroforestry. Restoration activities include 
labor inputs provided by women on a cash basis, thus improving household incomes. Activities 
to identify viable reduced emissions from deforestation and forest degradation and conservation 
and  enhancement  of  carbon  stocks  (REDD/REDD+)  pilot  sites  will  enable  the  project  to 
leverage incremental funding for forest protection and restoration (an additional 16,100 ha) from 
funds  specifically  set  up  to  promote  REDD.  The  commune  and  village  development  fund 
mechanism will be used as a decentralized local instrument to receive REDD funding for carbon 
sequestration. The project will also assist the selected districts in the provinces to establish 
inventory  sample  plots,  conduct  biodiversity  surveys,  and  draft  village/commune  forest 
management plans. 
 
12.  Output 3: Livelihoods improved and small-scale infrastructure support provided. 
Demand-driven livelihood and small-scale infrastructure subprojects prioritized in participatory 
consultations at the start of project will be identified and undergo a rigorous screening process. 
Each selected commune has a block allocation for livelihood improvements comprising NTFP 
production and processing, home gardens, livestock farming and other interventions selected by 
beneficiaries. Some of these livelihood options can also be pursued through the mechanism of 
the commune and village development funds, which will provide microfinancing facilities to 
households to borrow for their projects of choice. At least 4,775 households and more than 
4,000  farmers  will  receive  technical  and  cash  support  for  livelihood  and  productivity 
enhancement. In addition to livelihood interventions, the selected communes and villages will 
receive small-scale infrastructure support ($100,000 per village in the Lao PDR, $150,000 per 
commune in Cambodia, and $235,000 per commune in Viet Nam). Small-scale infrastructure 
support will primarily focus on (i) commune-based potable water schemes; (ii) provision of waste 
management and sanitation facilitations; and (iii) improvement and upgrading of rural access 
roads from communes to markets. Special attention will be given to ensure that the poor and 
ethnic minority groups participate equitably in subproject benefits.  
 
13.  Output 4: Project management and support services operationalized. The project 
will resource the management structures for a sector-like project that is supervised by the 
executing agencies in capital cities but implemented from provincially based provincial project 
management  units  (PPMUs)  and  provincial  project  offices  (PPOs).  The  central  project 
coordination units (CPCUs), central project management units (CPMUs), and national project 
management units (NPMUs) will coordinate (i) consultant recruitment and supervision; and (ii) 
procurement of materials, equipment, and vehicles during project implementation. Feasibility 
studies, and design and implementation of subprojects will be coordinated and supervised by 
the  PPMUs  and  PPOs.  Geographic  information  system  (GIS)-based  databases  will  be

5 
established for project performance monitoring. Regional baselines and predecision appraisals 
will build on the regional, national, and provincial data layers already established under the 
CEP-BCI and through the project preparatory technical assistance (TA).

15.  The government of Viet Nam has requested a loan in various currencies equivalent to 
SDR 19,162,000 from ADB’s Special Funds resources to help finance the project. The loan will 
have a 32-year term, including a grace period of 8 years, an interest rate of 1.0% per annum 
during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter, and such other terms and conditions 
set forth in the draft loan agreement. Interest during implementation will be capitalized. The 
government of Cambodia has requested a grant not exceeding $19 million and the government 
of the Lao PDR has requested a grant not exceeding $20 million from ADB’s Special Funds 
resources to help finance the project. ADB’s total contribution to the project will be $69.00 
million amounting to 89.9% of the total project cost. The governments will finance the equivalent 
of $5.63 million, to cover staff secondments to assist with subproject implementation, office 
space, as well as any economic and/or physical displacement associated with subprojects. 
Taxes and duties on civil works, services, and vehicles and equipment will be financed from the 
ADB loan and grant proceeds. Contributions from beneficiaries will be in-kind in the form of 
labor for surveys, demarcation, reforestation, and routine maintenance of proposed small-scale 
infrastructure (Table 2).

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  The  Ministry  of  Environment  (MOE)  and  the  Ministry  of  Agriculture,  Forestry  and 
Fisheries (MAFF) in Cambodia;21 the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry (MAF) in the Lao PDR; 
PF FP
and the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (MONRE) in Viet Nam will be the 
executing agencies. They will delegate responsibility for overall project coordination to their 
respective agencies: in Cambodia to MOE’s General Department of Administration for Nature 
Conservation  and  Protection  and  MAFF’s  Forestry  Administration;  in  the  Lao  PDR  to  the 
Department  of  Forestry;  and  in  Viet  Nam  to  the  Viet  Nam  Environment  Administration. 
Consistent with the governments’ desire to decentralize project implementation to the provinces, 
the implementing agencies will be the governor’s offices and executive committees or successor 
bodies in Cambodia; provincial agriculture forestry offices in the Lao PDR; and the departments 
of natural resources and environment under the provincial people’s committees in Viet Nam.  
 
17.  The  project  will  transfer  implementation  responsibilities  at  the  end  of  the  project 
preparatory  TA,  including  advance  preparations,  from  focal  points  in  MOE  to  MAFF  in 
Cambodia, and the Water Resources and Environment Administration (WREA) to MAF in the 
Lao PDR. Project preparatory TA counterpart staffing arrangements will be continued into the 
grant  and  loan  implementation  to  provide  uninterrupted  knowledge  support  and  optimize 
synergies gained during the project preparatory TA. MOE, WREA and MONRE will maintain 
their links with the GMS Working Group on Environment by reporting on project progress. They 
will also have a role in providing policy guidance on climate change and carrying out monitoring 
and  oversight  on  environment  and  social  safeguards.  The  GMS  Environment  Operations 
Center22  will  support  oversight  and  data  coordination,  as  well  as  implementation  through

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
19.  Project preparation and implementation for reforestation and restoration will (i) ensure 
that appropriate species are chosen for specific sites to optimize production, and (ii) improve 
and  protect  the  environment.  Most  of  the  livelihood  interventions  (agroforestry,  NTFP, 
agroprocessing) are either within the technical capacity of the provincial and district teams or 
can be easily procured through short-term consultancy inputs and other extension services 
within the target countries. Small-scale infrastructure priorities indicated by the beneficiaries 
revolve  around  water  wells  or  potable  water  schemes,  provision  of  latrines,  and  repair  or 
rehabilitation of rural access roads. Due to the mountainous terrain, greater attention to design 
and implementation quality will be needed. The focus of the civil works implementation will be 
on quality rather than maximizing coverage, and designs will be based on appropriate standards 
to ensure sustainability.

8   
B.  Economic and Financial 
 
20.  The economic viability of proposed interventions was assessed by adopting appropriate 
models applicable for the region. The project is expected to yield major benefits, including  
(i) incremental employment for households and local communities generated from proposed 
investments for boundary surveys, demarcation, inventories, and reforestation, that in turn will 
provide incentives to engage in corridor planning and management activities; (ii) improved 
livelihoods through innovative mechanisms to engage local communities in conservation and 
provision  of  essential  rural  infrastructure  facilities;  (iii)  access  to  safe  drinking  water  and 
avoidance of significant water-related diseases and health-care related costs; and (iv) public 
and  private  utilities,  enterprises,  and  downstream  farmers  benefiting  from  the  enhanced 
ecosystem services generated through the action of direct beneficiaries. The value of improved 
landscape management will include gains from increased carbon sequestration and resultant 
emission reductions; expanded ecotourism potential; and losses avoided from flood damage, 
extreme weather events, saltwater inundation of coastal aquifers, and costs associated with 
reduced and irregular river flow. The project is expected to generate social benefits that accrue 
to communities, local government units, and private and nongovernment organizations through 
stakeholder  empowerment  resulting  from  the  project’s  institutional  and  capacity-building 
interventions.  The  project  will  instill  among  the  stakeholders  a  sense  of  accountability  in 
sustaining and managing the local natural resource base. Analysis of representative investment 
models generated economic internal rates of return greater than the opportunity cost threshold 
of 12%, confirming that the project is economically viable.25 
PF FP
 
C.  Governance 
 
21.  All procurement to be financed by ADB loan and grant funds will be carried out in 
accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). Project 
implementation, procurement, and financial management will be aligned with the governments’ 
standard operating procedures. MOE, MAFF, MAF, and MONRE have given assurance that all 
accounts administered by the CPMU, CPCU, NPMU, PPMUs, and PPOs are consolidated and 
audited annually by auditors acceptable to ADB.26 The project will strengthen the capacities of 
PF FP
the CPMU, CPCU, PPMU, and PPO staff in financial management procedures to allow the 
efficient  operation  of  advance  accounts  and  the  reporting  of  financial  performance  to  the 
government  and  ADB.  The  project  will  establish  or  use  existing  ministerial  websites  to  (i) 
disclose implementation progress and bid notifications and their results, and (ii) provide a 
grievance mechanism against any corrupt practice. 
 
22.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the executing agencies in Cambodia, the Lao PDR, and Viet Nam. The specific policy 
requirements and supplementary measures are described in the PAM. 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
 
23.  The direct beneficiaries of the project are poor upland farmers, indigenous communities, 
and women living in and dependent on the forest ecosystem in 56 communes and 69 villages 
across Cambodia, the Lao PDR, and Viet Nam. 27 An estimated 35,000 households will benefit 
PF FP
from the project; the majority of whom are indigenous peoples in remote, mountainous areas. 
Average annual household incomes range from $160 to $450. Poverty rates among direct 
                                                 
25 Economic Analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). Detailed country-specific analysis 
P P
is  presented  in  Supplementary  Appendix  A  and  associated  Microsoft  Excel-based  models.  An  analysis  of 
ecosystem services within the biodiversity corridors is presented in Supplementary Appendix B. 
26 A good governance framework was prepared and is attached to the PAM for Cambodia. 
P27P Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
P P

9 
beneficiaries  of subprojects  range  from  25%  to  60%.  Investments  in stabilization  of forest 
resources  (restoration),  livelihood  interventions,  and  small-scale  infrastructure  will  improve 
incomes and food security of rural households in the corridors. Livelihood assets will be directly 
supported through the provision of land use rights.   
 
24.  The project is classified as effective gender mainstreaming as it addresses gender 
empowerment  by  narrowing  gender  disparities  through  access  to  economic  and  financial 
resources  and  opportunities  (i.e.,  land  with  security  of  land  tenure,  off-farm  employment 
opportunities) and enhancing voices and rights (i.e., representation in project decision-making 
bodies).  Further,  the  project  will  provide  women  in  the  target  communities  with  improved 
infrastructure that will enable increased productivity and incomes; reduced work burdens; and 
improved access to educational, health, and social services. For vulnerable groups (primarily 
households headed by women), preferential cash-based opportunities for employment will be 
available.  A  gender  action  plan  was  prepared28  to  facilitate  empowerment  of  women  for 
PF FP
participation  and  decision  making  in  all  aspects  of  corridor  management  and  investment 
activities. 
 
E.  Safeguards 
 
25.  Environment (category B). Project interventions in forest reforestation and protection 
will generate tangible and substantial environmental benefits. Any potentially adverse impacts 
associated  with  livelihood  improvement  and  small-scale  infrastructure  support  due  to  their 
location,  design,  construction,  and  operation  is  expected  to  be  minimal  or  insignificant. 
Moreover, subprojects will be screened to exclude those that may cause significant damage and 
provide  appropriate  mitigation  measures.  An  initial  environmental  examination  report  was 
prepared29 to comply with the requirements of ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) and is 
PF FP
based on ADB’s Environmental Assessment Guidelines (2003). 
 
26.  Involuntary resettlement (category B). No resettlement or physical displacement is 
expected because the small-scale infrastructure subprojects will be improved along existing 
rights-of-way, follow existing alignments, and based on priorities selected by beneficiaries as 
agreed in participatory, multistakeholder consultations at project start with voluntary in-kind 
commitments (i.e., labor, materials, land, right-of-way). A resettlement framework has been 
prepared and mitigating measures are incorporated in subproject selection criteria consistent 
with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement.30  
PF FP
 
27.  Indigenous peoples (category B). Indigenous peoples, ethnic minorities, and ethnic 
groups comprise the major beneficiaries of the project. The governments and ADB have agreed 
on an indigenous peoples planning framework.31 For most subprojects, where the majority of 
PF FP
beneficiaries are ethnic minorities, measures to improve their welfare and protect their rights will 
be included in the subproject design. Where appropriate, combined resettlement and indigenous 
peoples plans will be prepared. All data collected will be disaggregated by ethno-linguistic group 
and gender to allow for monitoring and evaluation of beneficiary inclusion.

IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITION 
  
29.  The governments have assured ADB that implementation of the project shall conform to 
all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, safeguards, 
gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail in the PAMs 
and loan and grant documents.  
 
30.  The governments have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, which are 
set forth in the loan and grant agreements. 
 
31.  As  a  condition  for  disbursement  of  funds,  the  governments  have  agreed  that  no 
disbursement shall be made to a project province until a PPMU or PPO has been established 
within the relevant agencies of that project province.  
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
32.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan and grants would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve 
 
 
(i)  the  loan  in  various  currencies  equivalent  to  SDR19,162,000  to  the  Socialist 
Republic  of  Viet  Nam  for  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  Biodiversity 
Conservation Corridors Project from ADB’s Special Funds resources with an 
interest charge at the rate 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per 
annum thereafter; for a term of 32 years, including a grace period of 8 years; and 
such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set 
forth in the draft loan agreement presented to the Board; 
(ii)  the grant not exceeding $19,000,000 to the Kingdom of Cambodia from ADB’s 
Special  Funds  resources,  for  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  Biodiversity 
Conservation Corridors Project, on terms and conditions that are substantially in 
accordance with those set forth in the draft grant agreement presented to the 
Board; and  
(iii)  the grant not exceeding $20,000,000 to the Lao People’s Democratic Republic 
from  ADB’s  Special  Funds  resources,  for  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion 
Biodiversity Conservation Corridors Project, on terms and conditions that are 
substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft grant agreement 
presented to the Board.
